bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, September 12, 1911

div1.p: Kean acknowledges that Agramonte should get proper credit for his yellow fever work. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, September 12, 1911
div1.opener:
K1
Sept. 12, 1911.
Dr. Aristides Agramonte,
Calle K, Entre 15 Y 17,
Vedado, Habana, Cuba.
My dear Doctor:-
div1.p:
Your letter of August 4th was duly received and I was glad to
hear from you. With regard to the republication of the Reed papers,
I am very sorry that the publication of one of yours was not included.
This collection was made and edited by Capt. Love, one of the Surgeon
General's assistants, and although he consulted me about it I am afraid
I did not give the matter as much attention as I should have or I would
have seen to it that the statement made in the former memorandum from
the office as to your share in the work was offset by an extract from
your letter to the Surgeon General, which is on file here. I was very
much occupied, however, by other matters and it was not brought to my
attention. I think if we had had on file any of your own publications
that Capt. Love would have put them in, but Capt. Love tells me that
he did not find any separate paper of yours in our files. If you have
copies of such I would be glad to have you sent them so that we shall
have them for reference and for future use in case of republication.
There really seems to be a fatality about your getting a proper state-
ment of your share in this work clearly before the public, though of
course your name appears in all the publications of the board and you
will observe that we have not failed to include your photograph with
K 2.
the others. When the time comes, however, for a monument to Walter Reed I
will see, if I am alive, that full justice is done you and I have put your
letter on file in connection with the publications.

I am going to sail on Sept. 30th on the White Star Line “Olympic” for
Paris to attend the Sanitary Conference which was originally called for the
26th of May. I understood that you were to be one of the Cuban representa-
tives and I hope to meet you in Paris, that is, unless you can manage to go
on the Olympic. Please sit down on the receipt of this letter and let me
know by return mail if you are going and, if so, where I will find you.
You should certainly be there to help see that proper action is taken with
regard to yellow fever. Please let me know what other representatives, if
any, will come from Cuba.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, (sgd) J.R.K. Lieut.-Colonel, Medical Corps, U.S.A.
